author: Emma Wynne
title: Perth childcare centres to make parents wear photo ID for drop offs amid security concerns - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Tue Feb 28 15:41:39 EST 2017 Photo To bolster security, several Perth childcare centres will now ask parents to wear photo ID. StockSnap.io: Freestocks.org 
A Perth childcare operator has introduced photo identification badges for parents in a bid to further bolster security. 
While some parents complained the measure was overkill and the tags would be a burden to remember, the centre's owners believed it was a necessary security measure. 
The School of Early Learning operates four centres in Perth's western suburbs and implemented the procedure following a review of its security procedures. 
Co-owner Brett Thomson said the review was prompted after a high-profile incident at a North Perth vacation care program last year , when two children were enticed from the centre and sexually assaulted before being abandoned in a park. 
Centre staff had been unaware the children were missing until they were notified by police with the operators later fined $40,000 over the incident . Review finds 'polite parents' breaching security 
"[That incident] prompted us to look at our own security measures and we brought a security firm in from outside to review everything," Mr Thomson told ABC Radio Perth . 
The centre already had entry-coded gates and had recently added CCTV cameras to all entrances, but he said the security review also recommended parents wear photo identification to pick-up and drop-off their children. 
The review found many parents were holding the gates open for each other. 
"Parents are polite and they do let in other people but they may not know who those people are," he said. 
"I'm a middle-aged man, I'm one of the owners of the business, but a lot of parents won't know me but they still hold the gate open for me." 
"Our centres are quite large; there might be 150 parents walking through the gate every day and there can be no expectation that every parent knows every other parent. 
"Really the only way to deal with that is put identification on everyone." 
Mr Thomson said most parents had accepted the need to wear the centre's photo ID tags. Overkill or necessary inconvenience? 
Some listeners to ABC Radio Perth said the measure was taking security measures too far. 
Stephanie: "It's overkill because there are times that the primary carers do give permission for a friend or relative to pick up the children." 
Dwain: "I am a day care operator. I would not expect that any normal day care operator would embrace photo ID to be worn by parents as we try to make day care more homely ... the most essential part of day care security is that the staff know each of the parents or carers personally. Photo ID isn't needed if the centre staff are doing their job and forming relationships." 
Others were more supportive. 
Jasmine: "I can understand how this is a minefield for childcare centres. While it might be a little inconvenient for me, ultimately the safety of the kids has to come first, and however a centre chooses to manage these situations needs to be supported." 
Tracey: "It's polite to hold doors open to people and it happens often that a parent will let in others out of politeness, not knowing if they are another parent whose child is attending the centre." Custody battles an increasing challenge 
Mr Thomson said the photo ID tags would also help staff manage situations where a child is the subject of a custody dispute between parents. 
Parents who attempt to subvert custody arrangements by picking children up from child care are a regular challenge for the centres. 
"It's becoming increasingly prevalent and court orders can be difficult to enforce â€” we unfortunately become the enforcers in those circumstances," Mr Thomson said. 
"I think the ID tag is going to assist in the process." Share
